Comment: I don't often meet Alekhine's Defence.  The idea of the opening is for Black to encourage White to overreach himself and then to strike back, exploiting the holes in White's defences.  So in planning to meet it, White either has to guard against over-exuberance or make sure that his attack wins quickly - not an option against a decent player of the Black pieces.

? Exposing Black's Queen too early in the game.  This contradicts opening principles generally and in the Alekhine particularly.  4...exd6 or 4....cxd6 were much safer.

The pawn has cost me the two bishops, allowed Black to develop his N on an ideal square and cost me two tempi.  I don't think I should have grabbed this pawn at all!  On the other hand, black is saddled with an immobile isolated pawn, so it's not all bad.
